bibl.title: Letter from Harry M. Hurd to Howard A. Kelly, February 24, 1908

div1.p: Hurd agrees with Kelly that Carroll's obituary overstates his accomplishments.

div1.head: Letter from Harry M. Hurd to Howard A. Kelly, February 24, 1908
div1.opener:
Form 134. 20,000-8-23-1907.
L
Keep
The Johns Hopkins Hospital,
NORTH BROADWAY.
BALTIMORE. February 24 1908
Dear Dr. Kelly,
div1.p:
Your letter is received. I
fully agree with you that the eulogy
of Carroll is so overdone as to do
him great harm. He was a diligent
and estimable man in restricted lives
and was not a “scholar”, “Connoisseur” or
“philanthropist etc,” in the ordering sense of these
words, indicating as they generally do a
man of wide knowledge and broad symphatisms,
The quotation at disclose is evidently a
reminescence of some man imperfectly
grounded in the scriptures. It at
any rate should not appear in
this form,

div1.opener:
Keep
James Carroll M. D. L L. D.
University of Maryland--University of Nebraska
Major and Surgeon, United States Army.
Professor of Pathology and Barctheriology of the George
Washington University and the Army Medical School, Washington,
D. C.
Born at Woolwich, England, June 5th, 1854.
Died at Washington, D. C., September 16th, 1907.
div1.p:

Scholar, writer, teacher and inspirer of youth, citizen

gical science, philanthropist, demonstrating for the benefit
of science and humanity, by voluntary submission to the bite
of an infected mosquito, whereby he suffered from a severe
attack of yellow fever, produced for the first time by experi-
ment, at the foreseen risk of two actual loss of life, the
cause of the propagation and spread of yellow fever; and by
this sublime deed becoming one of the most meritorious bene-

“Greater love hath no man shown than this, that a man
lay down his life for his country”.
